entry.title: Mo(o)re(â€”Sloan) fun with AcademicÂ Lineage
entry.summary:
While we were at the Mooreâ€”Sloan Data Science Environments community build, Jevin West continued our work analyzing academic lineage withÂ Myria.

On the citation graph weâ€™re using, InfoMap identifies 5,292 unique paper clusters. For each cluster, we took the top paper rated by Eigenfactor and fed these 5,292 papers as the seed set for the Least Common Ancestor (LCA) query which we ran on Myria. The query itself took a little over 4 hours, but it finishedÂ successfully.

Of the nearly 14 million pairs of papers, 7.1M of them have a common ancestorâ€”a hit rate of about 50%. Among these 7.1M LCAs, here are the ten most frequent papers (and theirÂ frequencies):

  1. (47,129) Some Methods for Strengthening the Common ğŒ2 Tests (Cochran,Â 1954)
  2. (35,585) The Evolution of Reciprocal Altruism (Trivers,Â 1971)
  3. (34,195) On the Mathematical Foundations of Theoretical Statistics (Fisher,Â 1922)
  4. (34,093) The Tragedy of the Commons (Hardin,Â 1968)
  5. (32,067) Some Difficulties of the Determination Problem (Harrison,Â 1933)
  6. (29,458) Diverse Doctrines of Evolution, Their Relation to the Practice of Science and of Life (Jennings,Â 1927)
  7. (28,149) An Analysis of Transformations (Box,Â 1964)
  8. (26,000) Fitting the Negative Binomial Distribution to Biological Data (Bliss,Â 1953)
  9. (25,410) A Method for Cluster Analysis (Edwards,Â 1965)
  10. (24,611) A Theory of the Allocation of Time (Becker,Â 1965)

We hope to dig into this more next week, but looking at the results is already prettyÂ fascinating:

  • These papers are generally highly cited, but (paraphrasing Jevin) may not be currently recognized as the very top according to standard citationÂ metrics.
  • The time range is pretty interesting â€” early to mid 20th century allÂ around.
  • Mathematics and statistics seems to dominate this part of the list. We do see some more fundamental life science papers nearby, the first of which is The Gene (Goldschmidt, 1928) atÂ #17.
  • The top hit represents 0.66%, or 1 in 151 of the results, and the 10th hit represents 0.34% or 1 in 289 of theÂ results.
  • And, of course, I have not directly come across any of these papers in my work, but I should go readÂ them!

What are your thoughts: Do you recognize these papers? Have you read them? What else should we thinkÂ about?

entry.title: 2014-09-23Â daily
entry.summary:
Today I met with Jevin West to continue our discussions of Sandra Andersonâ€™s work using Myria to study citation networks. This week, we are digging into one 37-hop citation path from neuroscience in 1988 to law in 1912. Really, really fascinating data. Soon, we hope to be able to automatically identify what the important papers that bridge disparate fields, and when these bridges wereÂ built.

In the afternoon, we held the eScience Welcome Event for Fall 2014 â€” we met all the new postdocs, faculty, and IGERT students who will be joining us this year. Now that school is back in session (starting tomorrow) the year is officially beginning, and I am so excited about whatâ€™s comingÂ up!

entry.title: 2014-09-19Â daily
entry.summary:
Today Sophie Clayton and I hacked on Myria for SeaFlow once again. We found another few opportunities for language and usability improvements, and made little progress because of an issue introduced when fixing other bugs earlier thisÂ week.

In the Myria research meeting, we had both Johannes Gehrke from Microsoft/Cornell and new/future UW database faculty Alvin Cheung at the Myria meeting. We talked about the real apps (Sophie, Sandra) that we implemented with Myria this summer and about future researchÂ ideas.

entry.title: 2014-09-16Â daily
entry.summary:
I also did not get much time to do real work today. There were three majorÂ activities:

  1. UW Data Science Incubator applications are due Thursday! They have started rolling in, so I have started looking at them and have started a few clarifying discussions with some of the authors. Getting excited for this secondÂ incarnation!

  2. Bill and Andrew and I met to discuss how to make the production Myria demo more stable. Some of the basic things like query queues are becoming important now that we have more users. Iâ€™ll work on that in the next fewÂ days.

  3. I pushed the least common ancestor query a bit farther by fixing a fairly major Myria bug â€” though, note that this was a performance bug and not a correctness bug :). Basically, we were sending a lot of data over the network when there was no need to do so. Fixing it sped up queries by a factor of 4â€”5, increased scaling dramatically, and dramatically reduced the variation in queryÂ time.

    At this point, I think I am finally done with the lineage query until I get to meet with Jevin West. MoreÂ later.

entry.title: 2014-09-15Â daily
entry.summary:
Next week, Iâ€™ll see if the incrementalization actually helps usÂ scale.

Only had a tiny bit of time today; I worked more on the least common ancestor query. Here is what new work contributed to betterÂ scaling:

  • Incrementalizing the code (duh) did in fact let me scale it farther. The prior program was failing because of memory problems in a large final join; breaking down that join into multiple steps, one at a time, inside the loop reduces the memoryÂ crunch.

  • Obvious Raco optimization: turn X = X + Y; into X += Y;, which is a big deal when X and Y both come from and are inserted into a database. (Here, + is UnionAll).

    The only reason this optimization had not been implemented before is that this was never actually theÂ bottleneck.

Once again, it goes to show what working with real data and real queries can do for your systemâ€™sÂ applicability.

entry.title: 2014-09-12Â daily
entry.summary:
Tomorrow I will work more on the scalingÂ issues!

We had a great Myria meeting this afternoon. We discussed Andrew Whitakerâ€˜s user-defined aggregate (UDA) extensions to MyriaL, which provide a very nice way to get scalable, distributed partial aggregation to implement many complicated aggregations in a single scan rather than through joins. The poster child is arg_max: return the entire row where the value of some field is maximized. Bill Howe has proposed a nice syntax that might help simplify the expression of arg_max-likeÂ UDAs.

I presented Sandraâ€™s least-common ancestor query to the group, and we discussed optimizations. At the meeting, Magda Balazinska, Bill, and Brandon Myers insisted this should work better if rewritten in incremental form, and Brandon helped me rewrite it afterwards. Next week, Iâ€™ll see if the incrementalization actually helps usÂ scale.

entry.title: 2014-09-11Â daily
entry.summary:
Today I spent all day with Sandra Andersonâ€™s citation graph lineage queries. Though I can compute â€œall-pairs reachabilityâ€ for the first 10000 papers in the datasetâ€¦ I can only currently compute â€œleast-common ancestorâ€ for the first 500 papers. There are some severe algorithmic scalability challenges here that we are excited toÂ tackle.

Part of the problem is that there are 2 million papers and it seems that about 2%â€”5% of all paper pairs have a common ancestor. This implies that the result set is pretty big â€” 200 billion papers. This does not scare us, but it is a good real useÂ case!

Due to data restrictions, we are working with anonymized paper IDs for this project and only Jevin has the secret mapping. To ensure that our computation is sensible, we sent him about 2300 pairs of papers and their least common ancestors, and he de-blinded some of the titles. The results are prettyÂ fascinating:

  • some of the least common ancestors are back in theÂ 1700â€™s
  • some of the least common ancestors are 54 citations deep from one of their papers (update: it appears this is probably bad data, because one such chain is actually anachronistic)
  • The common ancestors for papers in different fields are often old and seem really fundamental, e.g. (What is Capital?, I. Fisher, 1896) and (On the Mathematical Foundations of Theoretical Statistics, R. A. Fisher,Â 1922).

Tomorrow I will work more on the scalingÂ issues!

entry.title: 2014-09-10Â daily
entry.summary:
In between meetings, I spent most of today continuing yesterdayâ€™s work on the citation use case. Further query rewrites and testing exposed an interesting bug in the optimizer due to a mismatch between logical algebra representation and the actual system implementation behavior â€” the optimizer assumed the system could perform an operation which the system could not. Fixed the bug, which was thankfullyÂ short-lived!

After the last few daysâ€™ worth of heckling, what I believe is the largest computational step in the algorithm is now finished. At the start, it took about 4 hours to find shared citations 19 levels deep, at which point Myriaâ€™s built-in iteration limit (there to protect against infinite loops by bad queries that I write) was triggered. I raised the iteration limit and with all the improvements to Raco and to Myria, it now takes 4 hours to fully walk theÂ graph.

The longest train of citations is 69 levels deep! Tomorrow, I hope to find the actual shared citations for pairs ofÂ papers.

entry.title: 2014-09-09Â daily
entry.summary:
Today I picked up some of the work that Sandra Anderson did in her summer internship, namely trying to find common citations (transitively) between pairs of papers in Jevin Westâ€˜s dataÂ sets.

Once again I identified a number of nice optimizationÂ opportunities:

  • some query rewrites that result in better MyriaÂ plans
  • some relational algebra optimizations we were leaving on the floor in Raco
  • and some simple systems tricks to aggregate database inserts and thus amortize transaction overheads inÂ Myria.

The query rewrites are an especially interesting use case. Sandra wrote correct, fantastic MyriaL programs, but: since I know how the system works at a deep level, I can suggest rewrites that result in much more efficientÂ execution.

These queries that come from smart users and real science use cases are great as fodder for the future automatic query rewriting research I am planning on the side. In designing systems and services to make powerful tools accessible to scientists, the answer we give them when things are slow canâ€™t always be â€œwell, you wrote itÂ wrongâ€.

entry.title: 2014-09-04Â daily
entry.summary:
Today I met with UW CSE undergrad York Wei and Brandon Myers for demos and code review of Yorkâ€™s summer Project. York and Brandon have adapted our Myria Web frontend to extend the current support for Myria with the ability to issue queries to two newÂ backends:

  1. a backend that compiles and executes Raco-generated C code for fast, in-memory queries on a single machine,Â and
  2. a backend that compiles and executes Raco-generated code on the Grappa runtime, which uses the partitioned, global address space model to execute blazingly-fast queries in memory on a large, distributedÂ cluster.

Throughout the course of the meeting we discussed general issues and refactoring for Myria-Web so that it will truly be backend-agnostic and we can deploy this awesome, multi-system functionality on the web. I look forward to using this software for FlinkÂ support!

The other exciting news is that Andrew Whitaker finished the Raco support for user-defined aggregates and functions. We now have the support that Sandra Anderson needs to issue fast queries over citationÂ graphs!

entry.title: 2014-08-29Â daily
entry.summary: The big news today is that Myria now has support for user-defined aggregations. Iâ€™m excited that we can soon put this new feature to work and asymptotically speedup Sandraâ€™s citation graph analysis work, which is currently throttled by memoryÂ pressure.

entry.title: 2014-08-20Â daily
entry.summary:
Today I hacked more on the blog organization and layout; fighting with GitHub CNAMEs was harder than I expected it to be. Eventually I settled on creating a sub-project for the blog as hosting it in my personal dhalperi/dhalperi.github.io repository affected the URLs for other projects like the CSI Tool.

Met with Jevin West and Sandra Anderson to talk about Sandraâ€™s work on analyzing citation networks with Myria. Sandra is a rising sophomore at Cornell, of undecided major but spectacular in both CS and Math. She started 7 weeks ago with no prior experience â€œthinking like a databaseâ€, and in that time she has contributed lots of interesting ideas, independently re-derived much of the existing database wisdom about how to efficiently solve problems like transitive closure, and written some of the most complicated, iterative MyriaL programs to date. There will be a follow-up post on Sandraâ€™sÂ work!

More eScience steering committee action. We had our third session with the short-term evaluation team, which seems to be going great. So far, Veronica has managed to coerce 20+ fiercely independent minds to work together on the steps in our five-year vision for the project and to establish key evaluations. I need to learn more about the process and goals of evaluationâ€”-Iâ€™m having a hard time following along/understanding why weâ€™re doing what weâ€™re doing, but I can see amazing outputs from this processÂ already!

Some SQLShare planning and support. Seems like weâ€™re getting closer to needing/merging the rewrite of the Python client I started a yearÂ ago.
